## Anna Karenina's Impact on Polish Literature and Culture

In Polish film studies, there are three complementary approaches to defining film adaptations of literature. For Maryla Hopfinger, adaptation is an intersemiotic translation with a high coefficient of interpretation. Alicja Helman states that film adaptation and literary original are TWO DIFFERENT works on the same topic. In turn, Tadeusz Lubelski believes that the essence of adaptation arises from the tension between the time of the novel's creation (here: 1873-1877) and the time of film production (2012).

### Polish Film Education and Analysis

Joe Wright's "Anna Karenina" is an excellent opportunity to discuss this special case of the relationship between literature and film, which is film adaptation. A brief overview of types of literary adaptations will allow for more competent reception of this radical version of "Anna Karenina." ### Cultural References in Polish Educational Materials

The novel is widely studied in Polish schools and universities. Maria Cieśla-Korytowska wrote about Tolstoy's "Anna Karenina" in her book "Te książki zbójeckie" (These Bandit Books), Kraków 2011, pp.169-201.

### Polish Translations and Literary Reception

Tolstoy's books were translated into many languages, including Polish by translators such as Jadwiga Dmochowska, Czesław Jastrzębiec-Kozłowski, Kazimierz Truchanowski, and also Kazimiera Iłłakowiczówna.

### Contemporary Polish Literary Discourse

Polish literary criticism and educational platforms extensively analyze the novel. "I will repay, says the Lord" - the motto taken from the Letter to the Romans (12:19), with which Tolstoy prefaced the novel, was the subject of many interpretations and disputes. What did the writer really have in mind when placing it in his brilliant novel? Vikenty Veresaev, a Russian writer and doctor, noted in his "Memoirs": "In the spring of 1907, I was returning from abroad and from Warsaw I traveled in one compartment with a gentleman who turned out to be M. S. Sukhotin, Tolstoy's son-in-law. We talked a lot about Tolstoy, of course. [...] Among other things, I told Sukhotin how I understand the meaning of the epigraph to 'Anna Karenina' 'I will repay, says the Lord'".

The search results show that Anna Karenina has had a significant impact on Polish culture through translations, film adaptations, literary criticism, and educational materials. The novel continues to be studied and referenced in Polish academic and cultural discourse, particularly in discussions about adaptation theory and the relationship between literature and film.
